CatDescriptText: Lawrence Hungerford, painter, 6 South 27th Street and Herman F. Butler, candy store employee, 3 Arbor Street, were part of the "Pittsburghers Speak Up" column published in Pittsburgh Courier newspaper, December 5, 1959, pg. A1 with question: "Do you think that Negroes should press in the fight for civil rights, or should they seek them through such medium as conciliation, persuasion and patience?" Lawrence Hungerford's answer reads: "They should press, however when it comes to marriage, they should marry their own, the same as whites should do."  Herman F. Butler's answer reads: "Through patience, because, in my opinion, you gain more in the long run.  Although it is a slow process, it seems better because in using pressure you may overlook a lot of things which would not have been done if patience had been used.  Through pressure, you learn too late that some things were overlooked."
TitMainTitle: Two frames: Portrait of Lawrence Hungerford wearing dark zippered jacket with buttonhole on collar, and light colored t-shirt, standing in front of block building; Portrait of Herman F. Butler wearing dark cap, zippered cardigan, and dark zippered jacket with plaid yoke, standing in front of block building
